VIII.iv.3.C.1.a
.
Considerations for IU Claims
When deciding a claim for entitlement to a total evaluation due to individual unemployability (IU), the rating activity must consider
the economic and non-economic factors affecting a Veteran’s ability to secure and follow a substantially gainful occupation, and
whether
the disability requirements set forth in
38 CFR 4.16(a)
are met, or
extra-schedular consideration under
38 CFR 4.16(b)
is warranted.
When assessing the competence, credibility, and weight of evidence, no single factor has inherently more weight than another in determining the outcome of an IU rating decision once the evidence shows that the Veteran is no longer gainfully employed.
A decision maker must consider all factors contextually.  Assignment of weight for the different factors is and must remain contingent upon the entire evidentiary picture as found in the individual IU claim.
Important
:  Do not defer a decision as to the schedular degree of disability pending receipt of evidence sufficient to adjudicate the issue of IU.
References
:  For more information on
evaluating evidence, see
38 CFR 4.6
, and
M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, 1.A
separating the impact of service-connected (SC) disabilities from non-service-connected (NSC) disabilities, see
M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, 3.D.2.c
economic factors associated with IU determinations, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 3.A.2
non-economic factors associated with IU determinations, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 3.A.3
the evidence that must be discussed in the IU rating decision, see
M21-1, Part VIII, Subpart iv, 3.C.3.c
, and
assigning effective dates for IU decisions, see
M21-1, Part V, Subpart ii, 4.A.5.c
.
